title: AI / Open Q & A with Coach Keith - 2025-05-09

segments.speaker: Other
segments.text: Hello. Hello.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Was this cancelled?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Nope. It should be running. Maybe you're just very early or something.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: You might be the only one here so far. Last week was a small group. I think we're still ramping up again.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I was actually an old member from when this project started. It used to be Coke's Q&A hour, and now I'm starting to take it over again. The past couple weeks had only two people, so it might be a small group.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I saw it on the calendar and was just curious, so I jumped in to see what this is about.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Nice. How long have you been with Joy of Coding?

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm embarrassed to say, no worries.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: What are you interested in? Any interest in working in AI?

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Oh, so this is for AI? I see a lot about AI now. I'm curious about it. Maybe it's a good niche.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yeah, definitely a growing field.

segments.speaker: Other
segments.text: Hey, what's up, Matt? You're on mute.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Hi, Nick. I'm doing well.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Hi, Anna. Nice to meet you. I'm just curious. I doubt I'm at your level.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: All good.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I think today will be an official start time for me because since we last talked, I haven't done anything with it. I missed the last meeting because my wife just finished her semester, so I have more time now.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Nice.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I was catching up with the last meeting, looking over some documents Keith put together about next steps and what we want to do with the project. I also talked with Adam, who said it was very close to or launched in production.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: He mentioned Terraform or something else. I think he used SST, a JavaScript framework that works well with React and Node backends but not as easily for our Python project.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yeah, he was able to get the CodeTutor bot running on AWS, but the backend stuff to generate data in the database is still just uploaded what was current at that time.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is it all in one codebase?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It should be, but I wasn't around when he did that, so I don't know all the details.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Last time I talked with him, he said it had a bug. Do you know if it got fully working?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I don't know if it's still active. If you go to CodeTutor on the channel, you can check.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Let me check there myself.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is there a specific channel to be in or can I just hit it from anywhere?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I think you can do it from anywhere, but I don't think it works in direct messages yet.

chapters.title: Project Purpose and AI Chatbot Overview

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: You guys are working on a project for a real-life client, the Joy of Coding Academy itself. The project is a chatbot that works for the academy.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Currently, if you tag the help bot with a question, it fires off a Jira ticket and a human responds within 24 hours. The idea is to get an AI response quickly, with a human following up if the AI doesn't answer correctly.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The goal is to shorten response time, but AI projects require good practice, especially evaluations. You need a good set of questions and test data to tune prompts and parameters affecting the large language models.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: That makes sense.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Even traditional AI techniques need good test and training data, so you have to build out a database with questions, categories, keywords, and importantly, the right answers.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I work at a company processing healthcare claims. We're working on a chatbot and my boss emphasized having good scripts. We'll have one AI ask questions, another AI respond, and a third AI judge the response's accuracy.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That's a full AI cycle. You need a script with questions and an idea of correct answers, and you need hundreds or thousands of examples.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Do you work with health support people or business analysts to compile questions and answers?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, ideally you get questions and answers from subject matter experts, not engineers. Business analysts and help desk technicians who interact with customers are key sources.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I was a QA tester and worked with business analysts to get requirements for testing.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Exactly. You want the people who know the business side to provide the questions and answers.

chapters.title: Healthcare Claims AI Use Case and Team Roles

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The project involves prior authorizations for prescriptions. Some data comes electronically, but about 40% is faxed from doctor's offices and must be manually entered.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We have AI tools to extract data and answer questions, but to ensure they fit workflows, we have a working group including technicians who do the day-to-day work.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: So you still need human involvement. We're not at Star Trek level yet.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Not yet.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I've never worked with claims but know people who have. I was on the receiving end when I picked up my prescription yesterday.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, many humans behind the scenes pushing paper. Our job is to make their job easier.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I tested software processing insurance claims documentation, mostly automobile and property insurance.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Similar. At the end of the day, it's paperwork on the insurance side.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Are you interns?

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm an intern, and Nick is a coach guiding the project.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I was an intern, graduated from the program, now working full-time as an AI engineer, and came back as a coach.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: He had prior experience before joining Joy of Coding.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: That's why I need to stop dragging my feet on the technical interview. Mod one and two were easy for me since I had something to work with.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Logic is the main thing; code is just the tool.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm going to take the technical interview, and if I trip, I'll get back up and try again.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That's the only way to do it.

chapters.title: Open Q&A and AI Chatbot Testing

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: This is an open Q&A, so any questions are fair game.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I wouldn't know what to ask about AI. The only things that come to mind are R2D2 or C3PO.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Do you remember Clippy, the Microsoft helper? We plan to use a little cat thing as the first front end for our chatbot, with a graphical interface saying, 'Hi, I got your request. How can I help you?'

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: That would be so cool.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I looked at the bot's response to a question about making a list. It didn't find the document, so it used its existing knowledge. It might be an issue with database access.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Did you manually trigger it? It should check the database for knowledge.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It must be using prior knowledge since the database might be empty.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I tried messaging the bot directly with 'Who is Emily Hill?' but it didn't reply. It might only read from channels, not direct messages.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'd like to test this without all tests being visible.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We could make a private channel, but I'm not sure if we have privileges.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I don't know how to make channels.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We could run the bot locally again to create our own bots for testing.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I haven't run it locally.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Let's look into that.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: To troubleshoot database access, I assume I'd need AWS access?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes. Do you still have that?

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I don't think I was given access to the hosting permissions. I only have my personal AWS account.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Adam has the keys to the kingdom, as Emily would say.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: He sent me instructions last year. Let me check what I have.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: If you can't get in, we can try running it locally again since we have instructions.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I found the test server token but should probably delete it.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm past my free AWS year, and some free services might not be free anymore. Should I get a new account?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It's up to you. We should be able to work in the client's AWS account going forward. We used our own accounts before because it was faster.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We might set up better practices like CI/CD and work in their AWS account rather than personal ones.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I'm not sure if they set up a staging environment, but we should be able to work there. The database supports branching and versioning.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Normally, you have development or staging environments where you do your development.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: At my current job, we push pull requests against master, which triggers deployment to staging. Staging is a wild west environment where you have admin access and can test freely.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Once a week, code is pushed to UAT, user acceptance testing, which is closer to production and uses production data. It's a tightly controlled environment.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: After testing in UAT, code is pushed to production weekly.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We want to do something similar, ideally automated, pushing changes to the client's AWS account rather than personal accounts.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We need to get those environments set up again.

chapters.title: Planning to Run Project Locally and Next Steps

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We might want to get the project running locally again. Matt, do you want to try or should I drive while you watch?

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I can't find the email Adam sent with credentials.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That's fine. Running locally doesn't require credentials.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Okay, I'll share my screen and try to get it running.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Sounds good.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm signing in and looking at the README.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I realized recursion and sorting algorithms from module two are tricky.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, those are the hard parts and what interviewers mostly look for.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm in the middle of a big change, so I might start over.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: This is mostly Python, not React.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Hey Abu, welcome. Sorry you're late.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: No problem. This is my first time here. I'm just trying to see what's going on.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Nice. This was a Joy of Coding internship project to build an AI chatbot for the academy.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The chatbot uses previous Discord messages with retrieval augmented generation to answer student questions based on prior knowledge.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I was part of the project before, got a full-time job, and now I'm back as a coach to get it going again.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Matt was also previously on the project and rejoined.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Today we're starting from ground zero, trying to get the project running locally again as a working session.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Feel free to ask questions. This has historically been an open Q&A session.

chapters.title: AI Models and Amazon Bedrock Explanation

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is this an OpenAI project or do you use ChatGPT?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: OpenAI and ChatGPT are pretty much the same. We use the ChatGPT API through Amazon Bedrock.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The project was structured to test different inference engines or large language models (LLMs).

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Bedrock is Amazon's AI as a service platform, allowing us to swap different models easily on the same cloud provider.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: So you don't have multiple accounts with OpenAI or Claude, just one with Bedrock?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Exactly.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Do you store data or tokens locally or just use the models?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We store data in a database. We use retrieval augmented generation (RAG), which gives the model your own information by injecting relevant data into the prompt at runtime.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Training your own model or fine-tuning is expensive. RAG avoids that by grabbing relevant data from sources like Discord history and adding it to the context window.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: This way, no retraining or hosting your own models is needed.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We use embeddings and a vector database. Embeddings convert text or images into points in a high-dimensional space.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We cut Discord messages into chunks, run them through an embeddings model, and store the resulting vectors in a database.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: User queries go through the same embeddings model to produce vectors. We then use cosine similarity to find the most relevant documents.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The math is complex, but it works well. We tune parameters like how many documents to return and similarity thresholds.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The goal is to load enough relevant information into the context window to answer questions accurately without confusing the model.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We track precision and recall to measure if the bot answers correctly or gets confused by too much or too little information.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Evaluations are critical in applied AI projects.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I shared videos about evaluations and project management in AI. One covers common mistakes and why evaluations matter.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The other discusses end-to-end project management, focusing on upfront planning and finding the sweet spot between too many and too few documents.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Good questions so far. Any others?

chapters.title: Next Steps and Project Refactoring Discussion

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Looking at the time, my next step is to get this running locally.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, that could be easy or might have issues that take time.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Most work done was web development for the dashboard. Adam also cleaned up some Python code and disabled a few things.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Getting it running locally is a good next step. Then I'll talk to Adam about credentials for the cloud version.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We'll focus on setting up our process again: developing locally, pushing changes, adding tests, and improving workflow.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: When we met weeks ago, there was talk about starting fresh. Technologies have changed fast, so I want your input.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We don't need to start over completely, but some ETL parts were convoluted. We might split the Discord bot from ETL layers and simplify.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Agents are popular now. We can consider working with an AI agent versus the earlier approach.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: It depends on project goals. We need a clear idea of goals and target students.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, is it for all students or just those in the first few months? Those are different groups.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I think this is targeted for interns.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is it for navigating Joy of Coding or for solving coding problems? Those are different questions.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Exactly. We need a good test set of questions to define expectations and tune the bot.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We should restart conversations with Dr. Emily to clarify expectations since Joy of Coding is the client.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We want to resume regular meetings for feedback.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Step one is getting it running again and attracting interested folks.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Then we can do more project management properly with clear goals and evaluation sets.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It would be good to add tests and move toward test-driven development and continuous integration/continuous deployment workflows.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I don't remember the acronym TDD.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Test-driven development means writing tests first, then code to pass them.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Continuous integration means running tests automatically on pull requests to catch issues early.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: At work, running all tests can take up to an hour with thousands of tests.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We don't need that scale, but having some basic end-to-end tests helps developers get quick feedback and avoid breaking things.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Does anyone have any final questions?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: We'll continue general Q&A sessions. Feel free to ask about AI or working as an engineer in industry.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Even if you're not on the CodeTutor project, you can drop in anytime.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Thanks, Nick.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Thank you. Hope you enjoy the rest of your evening.

processing_notes: Removed filler words and speech disfluencies for clarity.
Corrected technical terminology and clarified ambiguous references.
Identified speakers as Host, Student, or Other based on context.
Segmented transcript into chapters by topic and conversation flow.
Preserved all substantive content and chronological order.
Transformed speech into coherent, readable prose with complete sentences.
